subject: Re: [junit] Testing a void method....
msgSnippet: ... What s the easy way to test that the PostgreSQL driver s close() method closes a database connection? I would prefer a response with code, but that s not
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>
> On 8/28/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...
> <mailto:simonpeterchappell%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> >
> > On 8/28/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...
> <mailto:cbeust%40google.com>> wrote:
> > > On 8/27/06, Chris Barham <cbarham@...
> <mailto:cbarham%40pobox.com>> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > On 8/26/06, Truong, David <david_truong@...
> <mailto:david_truong%40bmc.com>> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > >I have a question about testing a void method that it main
> purpose is
> > to
> > > > >close a connection.
> > > >
> > > > pass it a mock connection which has an expectation of a call on
> to the
> > > > close method.
> > >
> > >
> > > The danger with this approach is that if you upgrade your JDBC driver
> > and
> > > that in the new version, close() is broken, your test will keep passing
> > but
> > > your application will break...
> >
> > But are we supposed to be testing our tools or our code?
>
> We are supposed to make sure that if our tests pass, our code will work.
>
> I was just pointing out that using mocks in this situation would violate
> this simple assumption.
>
> I agree that in general, you should trust the layers you rely on, but if
> there is an easy way to test them as well, then why not do that instead of
> relying on mock objects that will lull you into a false sense of confidence?

What's the easy way to test that the PostgreSQL driver's close() method
closes a database connection? I would prefer a response with code, but
that's not required.
